data: The vocational college "Berufskolleg Hilden" as the sending organisation expands its international activities by searching and finding placements for students with organisations, enterprises and institutes in European countries, in order to reinforce their linguistic, inter-cultural and professional skills and knowledge. The 37 participants of the project belong to different sections: 2-year-course in biotech, 3-year-course in IT and students of commercial education. Before attending Berufskolleg Hilden these students decided to work in very different professional areas and have reached different qualifications and certificates. The above mentioned project includes 3 different activities matching the 3 different sections. At a very early stage all students are informed about the possibility of internships abroad. Their interest is also aroused by separate informative meetings held by former interns reporting about their experiences in foreign countries. They get information about current partners of the Berufskolleg Hilden and about organisational and financial aspects. At the same time the existing contacts are carried on to emerge the current data according to supervisors and contact persons. The individual facts are directly given to the participants in order to start a personal contact and relationship to the tutors at an early stage; i.e. before departure. In the section dealing with commercial education the students start their placement in cooperating companies and contact them through their employers. According to  the section/activity varies the duration of their stay.  In the biotech section the students stay abroad for at least 3 months, in the section of commercial education the stay is only 3 weeks and in the IT section the student stay for 2 months. When beeing abroad a continual contact between the  participants, the            tutors  and coordinators  in Hilden is secured. In addition to that a personal visit of the teachers in charge is effected; respectively in the BTA and IT sections. In the end the Training Agreement and the Europass will be worked out and signed mutually. All students write an internship report which is proof read and evaluated by their teachers. These reports offer an insight into the increase of language, professional skills and experiences, as well as into social and intercultural competences of the students. Furthermore the reports as well as presentations are used for evaluation. Posters and presentations function as a tool for spreading the results. Moreover organisations and other interested parties are informed by these activities in order to establish the Berufskolleg Hilden as School of Europe (Europaschule) focussing on the major target of internationality.

This consortium is made up of Good and Outstanding schools who are core members of a Primary Teaching School Alliance, and 3 additional schools who are key strategic partners and serve different needs of our locality.  The schools of the consortium are urban, and semi-rural,  they serve disadvantaged areas and affluent, they are small and large.  They encapsulate and represent the whole of Warrington and are ideally placed to jointly research, learn and develop new practice that will meet not only their own needs but the needs of the wider community of schools locally and regionally..  These schools are dedicated and focused upon creating an ideal learning community within the town and region and wish to push practice to the next level within their own schools and others.

In a climate of disappearing school budgets and pressure upon reaching and maintaining progress measures we feel that staff CPD is too often neglected, causing a climate of inevitably lowering standards and insular practice.  This is an emerging risk in the areas of wider curriculum due to potential over emphasis on core subjects, and in Early Years  practice following the national roll out of extended provision and a new funding formula.  This project offers us the opportunity to challenge this and to look to international approaches to learn and disseminate from the best examples of teaching and learning practice, ensuring that children outcomes are improved in a variety of measures.

We wish to focus upon key areas which we feel would be most beneficial to the schools in our area, we have looked at our school development plans, analysed progress data and taken the local context into account, for example we have considered the skills profile predicted for regional employment needs and chosen subject areas accordingly.
In carrying out our project we have identified a number of training opportunities we wish to send a number of teaching professionals on in a variety of European countries.  The areas of training we have chosen are: Early Years Practice, Leadership of Early Years, STEM subject enhancement, MFL - Spanish.

Early Years is a current area of strength for Warrington as a town, however we feel that this can be improved significantly by looking internationally accepted best practice as delivered in Sweden and Italy.  Our Early Years practitioners are passionate and wish to move their areas on through immersion and reflection on how two approaches; Swedens outdoor-based approach to development through play and Italys focus on 'beauty' in indoor provision, can be adapted to perfectly suit the needs of our children and locality.  The two approaches developed in different economic climates we feel when combined will serve our own mix of socio-economic pressures and will allow the development of an innovative practice for the North West and beyond. We place such importance upon excellence in Early Years education that we wish to make this activity the largest in our project.  We will select 10 membeers of staff from across our consortium to attend these courses.  There will be senior leaders attending to direct the strategic development of practice to be brought home, alongside newly qualified teaching staff and teaching assistants to embed great practice from the start of their careers.

STEM subjects have been identified as an area of difficulty in some schools who find a lack of expertise within their profile of employees.  A vital curriculum area which must be taught with passion and knowledge we feel that an upskilling of key subject leaders across our consortium will enable renewed confidence in introducing a love for these subjects in our children.  An area of skills weakness for large areas of England, we feel we must begin to address this at a primary education level to begin to address this.  We will send 6 staff members from consortium schools on this training, they will be a mixed group of new staff members and subject leaders, this mix will enable all perspectives to be immersed in the experience to ensure a rounded and thorough learning experience is gained by the whole group.

The schools who make up our consortium have significant experience in managing and delivering international project over the years with trips having been made to Denmark, New Zealand and South Africa.  The teaching school alliance which is linked to the consortium has a recognised expertise in large scale research projects and in the provision of continuing professional development.   

The reputation of Warrington Teaching School Alliance nationally makes it ideally placed to disseminate the evidence based findings of this project as detailed in the Impact section of this form.

The decision to apply for Erasmus+ was taken to improve the quality first teaching and the passion for languages within our school. We hope that staff of varying language proficiency will be able to deliver outstanding language lessons that can inspire the next generation of linguists.  We recognise the importance of learning about new languages and cultures, as well as the benefits and positive impact it can have on our pupils' education.  The UK has an alarming shortage of people able to speak another language and we hope that through this project we will provide our children with both the skills, and also the desire to change this. We have worked hard to forge strong ties with our feeder secondary schools and develop our implementation of the language curriculum but feel further CPD would ensure the longevity and impact of languages for pupils within our school. We are currently members of a wider community of primary schools that subscribe to a language network that provides resources and tools for the teaching of languages in school, though many of our staff lack confidence in delivering this to the children. This is an area of improvement that we want to rectify in order to provide our pupils with high quality language teaching.

Training will take place in France, the main language that is currently taught at our Primary School.  Our aim is to forge meaningful ties with partner schools in the region, where staff can share good practice and our pupils can engage and understand a different language and culture. In our school currently, there is a shortage of qualified teachers that have the confidence to teach French. We feel that the CPD offered through this programme would allow our teachers to develop their language skill set and be invaluable to the development of languages within school.  This CPD would then be disseminated to other members of staff through a training day and staff meetings with its progress and impact on the children being monitored by our language leader in school. Phase two of our action plan will be to send more competent staff to engage directly with the CPD to enhance their skills and delivery of the language.

We aim for this project to have a positive impact on the long term learning of another language for our children. Enjoyment of the subject is a key focus for us as staff to ensure that children are engaged in their learning of this subject. We aim to immerse the children in the development of language skills and also in experiencing other cultures. As part of our ambition to develop a cross phase curriculum from years five to eight, spanning key stage two to three, we aim to use the skills developed at primary level, to ensure that there is no decline in pupil outcomes, as well as an increased participation at GCSE level and higher learning. Therefore, addressing the current national language crisis. 348 children will be involved in this project with a further 90+ planned in the future with secondary links. 

The activities that we will undertake as part of the programme will first and foremost be language based. Through our international contacts we plan to source high quality CPD that addresses the gaps in language understanding and fluency. Furthermore, we aim to understand how an outstanding language lesson should be delivered. 

We plan to send 3 members of staff on each of our training events. In the first instance, this will consist of our Primary Foreign Languages leader, a member of the senior leadership team and a class teacher all from KS2. The language leader will oversee the implementation of staff training as well as assessing the progress of the children. The senior leader will be responsible for monitoring the implementation of the training received, as well as ensuring that resources and tools are available where necessary. Both will ensure that this is high profile and that staff are compliant in following the implementation of the new programme.  Also attending will be a KS2 class teacher to assist in the implementation of new ideas and concepts gathered from France.

Since the changes to the national curriculum, a higher emphasis has been placed on languages within primary schools. Through the training courses that we will attend, we expect to see an immediate impact in the way languages are taught in school. We will ensure that teachers are given the tools and resources necessary to provide outstanding lessons to engage and motivate our pupils. Through the programme, we will seek to create new ties with other schools in the region we are visiting and use this as an opportunity for our children to feel comfortable and understand a different language. Our aim is to create ties with other primary schools in which older children would be able to take part in an exchange visit and use their language skills first hand with one another. Impact will be measured in pupil outcomes and the sustainability of children learning an additional language.

Our school is a medium sized primary school with 220 pupils on roll, aging from 2-11. We are situated in a deprived area of Warrington and children enter the school with low levels of literacy and numerical skills.
We are participating in these language training courses to target the current needs of our school. These include; the need to improve the teaching and learning of languages, staff confidence and competence, the leadership of languages and the sustainability of language teaching. 
The project involves sending 3 teachers, over a 2 year period to France. Their training will involve methodology and pedagogy sessions and liaising with a link school in Toulouse. It is expected that participating in these training courses, will equip the staff involved with increased language skills - especially in speaking and listening - increase their competence, confidence, independence and enthusiasm. Furthermore the initial participant is the languages lead in the school, so her leadership ability will be strengthened through being given the opportunity to liaise with other subject leaders on the course, discuss pedagogy, look at relevant documents and immerse in the long term vision for our school. The fact that we will have a link with a school in Toulouse will ensure that long term sustainability is achieved, through participating in shared projects and cross curricular themes, such as carnivals, about town and food.
After each training course, the participants will be expected to share not just what they have done, but what they have learned with all 20 staff in the school, through INSET training and twilight sessions. They will also feedback to the Senior Leadership Team and the Focus group who are responsible for languages. The initial participant, who is the languages lead, will  be responsible for involving the wider community, through invitations to assemblies and also be responsible for feeding back to governors, through interim governing body meetings.
The expected impact is that teachers will develop greater skills in teaching languages. They will also gain more confidence and competence through the day to day usage of the target language with native speakers and the staff and children of the link school. Also the language leader will have her leadership strengthened, through having a team of people who will have received the same quality and consistency in training, which will in turn enthuse other members of staff and develop their language skill and confidence. For the 220 children, it is expected that there will be an impact on the children's speaking and listening skills, as these are what will be most improved for the participating members of staff. In addition the children's reading and writing skills will be improved through the use of writing emails, letters or blogging children from the link school. As we are a school from a deprived area, supporting children with initial low literacy and numerical skills, these courses will have a huge impact on the children's intercultural understanding. Language learning will be real and purposeful for the children, opening up further opportunities that may inspire them and increase their aspirations for later life, such as continuing to pursue language learning or gaining a job that requires a passion or skill in the development of languages. 
The dissemination and evaluation of the project will be overseen by the Senior Leadership Team, the Head Teacher and the language leader in the school. Dissemination to staff will take the form of INSET days and twilight sessions, sharing methodology ideas, assessment strategies and resources. For the children it will take the form of the language teaching sessions themselves through the use of pictures, books, flashcards, blogging, writing letters and emails to the link school and assemblies. For the governors it will be disseminated through interim governing body meetings whereby the initial baseline assessments will be shared and then the on going assessments and statistics of the improvement of languages. The improvement in staffs' language skills, confidence and competence and the progression of their language skills and that of the children, will be monitored by the language leader and the Focus group, through drop ins, developmental observations, evidence of displays and signs and using the Europass and a local authority scheme of work assessment package, that is in line with the new assessment requirements of 2014.
The long term benefits of this project, are that we will develop confident and competent language teachers who are inspired and enthusiastic, which in turn inspires and enthuses the children we teach. Ultimately, we envisage that children leave with the expected language skills for the end of KS2. The sustainability of the language learning will increase with our link to a school in Toulouse, which will also provide the children with a real and purposeful reason for learning languages.

Barrow Hall  is a large three form entry Primary school in an urban area in Warrington, Cheshire. The learning of Spanish spreads throughout Lower and Upper key stage two whilst Key Stage one focuses on basic German and some French. As a whole staff we are determined to build on the current strengths of our school. We value the learning of MFL throughout the school as it allows children to be accustomed to other cultures and traditions.  We are a forward thinking school and are keen to extend our global outlook by undertaking staff training abroad and engaging in international projects and partnerships. 

The majority of teachers in our school have had no language training aboard and we wish to upskill our teachers in this area. Our aim is to increase teachers' confidence and self esteem in integrating languages into their practice (Spanish and French) as well as improving their language skills. We wish for staff to attend language training courses abroad over the next two years. These staff will attend CPD provision whether experienced, recently or newly qualified. This will result in the quality of teaching and learning across the school.

Our management team are keen to acquire knowledge and skills on how other countries in the EU ensure the professional development of all their teachers and how this impacts on their pedagogies and learning of all children. We wish to increase awareness of leadership around Europe by sharing new initiatives and ideas about best practice.  We aim to promote internationalism throughout our school by staff visiting European countries for cultural exchange.  

Teachers attending training courses in Spain and France will receive upskilling in language competencies through immersion of international training courses. We aim to send 2 groups of 3 teachers twice a year to Spain and 1 group of 3 teachers once a year to France (over a two year period). Training courses will take place during half term in either October 2015/2016, February 2016/2017 or May 2016/2017. Participants will be selected by their current development needs and the needs to the school.  We expect teachers to undergo initial French  and Spanish language lessons in the UK and they will then experience language courses by reputable training providers in French and Spanish speaking countries. 

A whole school priority for the leadership team, including the Head teacher, is to focus on the professional development of all teachers within our school; from experienced to newly qualified. Having the opportunity to observe best practice of professional development in other EU countries , will allow our team to gain invaluable experiences, knowledge and understanding of other countries professional development methodologies.  We aim to send to 8 members of the Senior leadership and Middle management team to Sweden over two years (one course per year).

All staff attending European courses will receive a certificate of training from the course providers. 

The expected impact will see an increased confidence from our staff in the teaching of languages as an individual lesson and cross curricular. Through immersion of other cultures and the methodologies that underpin their teaching pedagogy, teachers will take away new initiatives and ideas that will inspire their teaching approach of the languages.  We want to see children being introduced to two languages by 2017- Spanish and French. As well as this, the school will benefit from promoting and making children aware of the European dimension and how the children are connected to global community. Over time, teachers implementation of these new ideas will develop the quality of their teaching as a whole as well as the impact on childrens' learning. We aim to see the majority of our staff skilled in cross cultural teaching. 

By observing how other EU countries provide professional development for their staff,  we hope to incorporate their findings into our school in order to improve the quality of teaching and learning. By providing teachers with other means of professional development and best practice, we endeavour to see the confidence of teachers develop in order  to promote language and cultural learning. 

Our Head teacher is a part of an alliance with other schools in the Warrington area. By being involved in this alliance, we will share our outcomes with this alliance which will then be incorporated into other schools in the area. The alliance also runs programmes for newly and recently qualified teachers that will enable our outcomes to be implemented into these programmes of study. In order to ensure community awareness, publication of our schools mobilities will be issued on the school website and in the local newspaper.
Developing Skills for Teaching Languages to Primary Children

As our children currently have minimal experience and exposure to languages through school but have a passion and desire, and show great potential to learn, the key aim of this project is to improve the level of competences and skills for our staff to deliver quality language provision in our school. We aim to develop a passion and desire for Lifelong Learning of Language, to give our children the opportunity to embrace cultural awareness to become equipped for the future to tap to into the opportunities that can be found in the global environment.  
The objective of the project is to change attitude and increase confidence and competence when delivering French across school for all staff. To develop a clear plan of progression, to develop language skills from Early Years through to Year 6 ensuring this is sustained and embedded into our school curriculum in  preparation for the significant changes being made in September to the MFL curriculum and requirements in schools. as part of  our commitment to raising global and cultural awareness in our children and building  their lust for languages. 
School plans to send three members of staff over a two year period, to develop a strong team to teach and support the teaching and learning  throughout school. The first participant will be schools Higher Level Teaching Assistant who has previously taught French across school as part of PPA provision and also runs an after school French club. She is a frequent visitor to France and has some knowledge of French and a strong desire to become more fluent and competent , and to improve her skills which will then enable her to share and develop this across school.  She is confident in delivering this subject and is passionate and enthusiastic  to drive improvements in Teaching and Learning of French in our school. Further members to be selected at a later date,then to attend immersion courses over the the two year project which will give us the opportunity to identify and fill any gaps we may have.
Activities during the visit will include intensive language training and the opportunity to visit a school to experience teaching in a European school first hand and to talk to children about their experiences of learning another language. The course gives the opportunity to immerse in the village life of provincial France.  Including selected activities including meeting  the Mayor, traditional dancing and games. Living and speaking French for a week!
School is to develop an action plan to carry out this project to measure the impact it has. We will measure where we feel we are at now via surveys and pupil interviews, identify requirements and begin to Schools data tracking  will be developed to ensure progression which will measure the impact of the project.
 Our vision is to embrace this opportunity and develop staff competence providing the tools to teach French competently. School has therefore to ensure support is in place for professional development in terms of language skills and the pedagogy of language teaching, to ensure we have staff skilled in delivering quality language provision and to embed languages into our school developing cross curricular links and finding a partner school to make learning languages a real life experience for our children. We aim is to change attitude and increase confidence and competence when delivering French across school for all staff.
School aims to develop a clear plan of progression, to develop language skills from Early Years through to Year 6 ensuring this is sustained and embedded into our school curriculum as part of  our commitment to raising global and cultural awareness in our children and building  their lust for languagesImprove the teaching and learning of languages to promote linguistic diversity and inter cultural awareness

We aim is to develop a greater knowledge and understanding of the French culture and transfer these skills via cpd to school staff and to our children. We want to allow our children the opportunity  to embrace other cultures, values and beliefs and to encourage investigation into other languages and desire to travel and experience. 
To introduce a new language in early years education to discover and enjoy other languages and cultures.
Long term we intend to embed the teaching of MFL in our school and open up other languages to take our children to develop their lust for languages and expand their world. To prepare our children for life, to make them aware that the world is big, and that in the world not everyone can speak English
Marketable sludge derivatives from sustainable processing of wastewater in a highly integrated treatment plant

This project researches, develops and demonstrates a toolkit of novel processes together with market development for advanced sludge-derived products and integration methodologies that can be applied to a range of wastewater treatment plants based on a typical municipal scenario. Supporting economic and life cycle assessment of the resulting gains in energy efficiency and conversion of renewable carbon, together with an implementation strategy based on a product mix with optimal value, will inform step changes that contribute to achieving more secure and sustainable sludge treatment and management practices in Europe while reducing pressure on natural resources and reliance on manufactured fertilisers.  Addressing key sludge management issues in the context of EU climate change mitigation and energy policies, the project concentrates on novel processes for sludge volume reduction, more efficient treatment and downstream processing for high quality sludge derivatives together with application protocols and assessment of the pathogen risk and long term soil impact for greater public confidence. Using an integrated approach with emphasis on the whole wastewater treatment system, the project promises innovative system solutions that have the potential to achieve up 20% annual carbon savings for the water industry by 2020 and ultimately could deliver up to 15,791,131 tCO2e pa savings for Europe.  Composing of 14 partners including 7 SMEs from industry, academia and Government establishments, the Consortium is a balanced mix of highly qualified and committed individuals that are well-placed to tackle the technical challenges, disseminate the results and to exploit the €17.5 billion market for new environmental equipment that will be opened up by the project.
Sustainable products from economic processing of biomass in highly integrated biorefineries

Economic and sustainable production of fuels, chemicals and materials from biomass requires capture of the maximum energy and monetary value from sustainable feedstock. SUPRA-BIO achieves this by focussing on innovative research and development of critical unit operations, by using process intensification to match economic production to the scale of available feedstock and by process integration that provides energy from process waste, optimises utilities to minimise environmental impact and maximises value from the product mix. A technology toolbox for conversion and separation operations is developed that adapts to various scenarios of product mix and feedstock. These are contextualized by full life cycle and economic analysis of potential biorefinery schemes. Based on lignocellulose, microbial/organic waste or microalgae feedstock, innovation and intensification are used to improve the economics and carbon efficiency of fractionation, separation, bio and thermochemical conversions to produce biofuels, intermediates and high value products. Strain selection, genetic manipulation, molecular design and nanocatalysis are used to improve productivity and selectivity; reactor design, intensification and utilities integration for economics. Fermentation to 2,3 butanediol is demonstrated. Mono and multiculture processes are researched for high value products and feedstock streams. Separation is developed for omega oils and specific lignochemicals. Nano and biocatalytic processes are developed for biofuels and bioactive molecules. Integration into potential biorefinery schemes is explored in laboratory pilots of integrated reactors, by piloting on sidestreams, by exchanging separated fractions between partners and by process evaluations. The project includes all the scientific, engineering and industrial skills required to produce the step changes required for biorefineries to impact significantly on realising the aims of the European Strategic Energy Technology Plan
The Extensive and Ubiquitous Role of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) in Space

Large Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon (PAH) molecules are deeply interwoven in the fabric of the Universe and lock up ~15% of the elemental carbon in the interstellar medium (ISM) of galaxies. They dominate the mid-infrared emission characteristics of galaxies that can be used to trace star formation locally as well as in the early universe, they influence the phase structure of the ISM and the star formation rate of galaxies, and they are the epitome of molecular complexity in space, heralding the importance of top-down chemistry. In spite of the influential role of PAHs in the ISM, their lifecycle, catalytic activity, interaction with interstellar radiation, gas and grains and their role in the organic inventory of solar system bodies is still poorly understood. The EUROPAH ETN aims to change this by creating a highly multidisciplinary network that combines astronomy, molecular physics, molecular spectroscopy, environmental science, quantum chemistry, surface sciences, and plasma physics in a comprehensive research and training program. EUROPAH will train 16 ESRs through cutting edge individual research and innovation projects investigating key physical and chemical processes of PAHs in space and related terrestrial settings and linking directly to R&D needs of our industrial beneficiaries. EUROPAH will engage all ESRs in industry driven innovation activities aimed at R&D of the industrial participants products and services, including outreach activities led by our industrial science communication beneficiary. Research and innovation training is complemented by an extensive program of network-wide training events to expose ESRs to all disciplines in the network and to instill in them a comprehensive set of transferable skills. This will provide the ESRs with a unique learning environment in a multidisciplinary setting aimed at developing a research oriented creative and innovative mind set and will place them well for a future career in academia or in industry.
Nano- Electrospun Filter for Efficient Liberation & Encapsulation of acticides for water treatment in transportation applications

'In recent years, word of aircraft water quality issues has spread, generating negative media coverage, attracting the attention of regulators worldwide, and giving airline passengers a new cause for concern. Health enforcement agencies are currently in the process of drafting new, more stringent quality regulations for aircraft potable water and the world's other regulators will follow suit.
Aircraft potable water is typically loaded from municipal systems which are susceptible to contamination. While municipal water quality has always been a concern in some parts of the world, it is now becoming an issue in North America as well. As recent outbreaks of waterborne disease in carries Canada and the US illustrate, dependence on any municipal water supply carries an inherent risk. Even when the source water is clean, contamination can make its way into a water supply during ground handling because of contaminated water trucks, contaminated hoses, or from improper handling procedures by ramp crew.
The aircraft water system itself can be the source of contamination. Microorganisms can grow within the water tanks, water lines, and even the water filters. This situation is exacerbated by the standard, air pressurized water systems that allow water to remain still in the tank and distribution lines until a faucet is opened and the water begins to move. Bacteria thrive in such conditions, which also encourage bacterial regrowth almost immediately after system cleaning.
The present project aims to provide an advanced treatment system which will make use of core/sheath polymer nanofibres which are filled with biocidal substances. This will provide a way of maintaining a constant level of biocide in the water without the need to dose or measure the quantities present. In addition the nanofibres will provide a means of physical entrapment for viruses.'
Ash Ingestion Detection Apparatus for aircraft

Aircraft frequently encounter volcanic ash when airborne. In the aftermath of these encounters, virtually the entire fuselage of an aircraft can be contaminated with ash, necessitating a thorough cleaning of the cockpit, instrument panel, circuit breaker panels, passenger and baggage compartments. The electrical and avionics units can be so heavily contaminated that complete replacement is necessary, mainly due to the possibility that all the units could have suffered from overheating. The ash also contaminates the cargo-hold fire-warning system and can generate nuisance fire warnings which are due to the volcanic ash in the air rather than smoke from a fire.
The present proposal aims to provide an advanced airborne volcanic ash detection apparatus which will make use of special machine vision interrogation of volcanic ash (tephra) and novel image analysis software. The integrated retrofittable system will examine air in the aircraft’s ventilation ducts.  By interrogating foreign bodies in the fresh air entering the cabin and identifying the type, size and number of particles per unit time and inferring the presence of low level ash particles in the possible presence of other solids in the air e.g. sand etc an early warning may be conveyed to the crew whence appropriate action may be taken to reduce the exposure of the aircraft, thus making possible enormous savings on maintenance costs.
